title: Simulation and the crossLag Package
text: Yet, uncommon researchers use statistical techniques identify causal mechanisms, occasionally little theorizing data generating process. One statistical technique cross-lagged panel model (CLPM). CLPM variant Autoregressive Distributed Lag model used econometrics, identified causal mechanism particular type causality, Granger Causality. reasoning simple. notion one measures \(x\) time \(t-1\) \(t\), \(y\) time \(t-1\) \(t\), one estimates model predicts \(y_{t}\) \(x_{t-1}\) \(y_{t-1}\), additional model \(x_{t}\) predicted \(y_{t-1}\) \(x_{t-1}\). temporal ordering data used identify causal relationships. Although one may able manipulate \(x\) \(t\) – rule spurious relationships – \(x\) measured past predicts \(y\) present, \(y\) measured past doesn’t predict \(x\) present, one can reasonably certain causal ordering \(x\) affects \(y\) \(y\) affect \(x\). Graphically, model can represented Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG, Pearl 2001).  CLPM variant Autoregressive Distributed Lag model used econometrics, causal mechanism identified often referred Granger Causality. Granger causality concept means \(x\) measured time \(t-1\) predicts \(y\) time \(t\), \(x\) Granger causes \(y\). CLPM can written $$y_{t, }=a_0 + a_1 y_{t-1, } + a_2 x_{t-1, } + e_{1,} $$ conclusions CLPM attempts leverage temporal order variables observed. one estimate two equations using traditional regression techniques, large \(a_2\) coefficient represents causal relationship \(x_1\rightarrow y_2\); whereas large \(b_2\) coefficient translates reversed effect, .e., \(y_1 \rightarrow x_2\). \(a_2\) large \(b_2\) effectively zero, tempting conclude \(x\) causes \(y\) \(y\) cause \(x\). cases, include lagged value dependent variable, \(y_{t-1, }\) \(x_{t-1, }\), control effect dependent variable; unit serves control, baseline. \(a_2\) \(b_2\) reach conventional levels statistical significance, tempting conclude causal effect identified. Economists refer Granger Causality, statistical test whether lagged value independent variable can predict dependent variable controlling lagged value dependent variable. reasoning simple, rather strong assumptions data generating process must made. several issues arise upon estimating model. first pertains empirical consequence including lagged realization independent variable regression model, rather contemporaneous effects; second issue pertains inclusion lagged dependent variable (Allison 1990); third revolves around identification causal effects, particularly unobserved confounders stable unit effects.
code: library(dagitty) library(ggdag) library(ggplot2) options(repr.plot.width = 2, repr.plot.height = 2)  # Set smaller plot size g <- dagitty("dag {     X1 -> Y2      Y1 -> Y2     X1 -> X2      Y1 -> X2  }") coordinates(g) <- list(     x=c(U1=0.5, Y1=1,X1=1,Y2=2,X2=2, U2=3),     y=c(U1=1.5, Y1=1,X1=2,Y2=1,X2=2, U2=2.5) ) ggdag(g, text = TRUE) + theme_dag() + ggtitle("Figure 1: The Cross-Lagged Regression (CLR) Model") x_{t, i}=b_0 + b_1 y_{t-1, i} + b_2 x_{t-1, i} + e_{2,i}

title: Simulation and the crossLag Package
Simulation and the crossLag Package
text: Simulate five trials, three wave panel, cross lag effects, weak person stability, confounding. \(\texttt{monteCarlo}\) function simulates data several DGP models: “clpm,” “ri-clpm,” “dual-change” model. simulation wrapper estimates OLS lagged independent dependent variables.
code: library(crossLag) library(dplyr) monteCarlo(     trials = 5,     waves = 3,     model = "ols",     data_generation = "ri-clpm",     within_person_stability_x = 0.1,     within_person_stability_y = 0.1,     cross_lag_x = 0,     cross_lag_y = 0,     confound = 0,     variance_x = 1,     variance_y = 1,     sample_size = 1000) %>% head() ##   confound within_person_stability_x within_person_stability_y         xlag ## 1        0                       0.1                       0.1  0.019895582 ## 2        0                       0.1                       0.1  0.001196225 ## 3        0                       0.1                       0.1 -0.012555982 ## 4        0                       0.1                       0.1  0.002984921 ## 5        0                       0.1                       0.1  0.010791678 ##         ylag trial model data_generation ## 1 0.03054901     1   ols         ri-clpm ## 2 0.07300999     2   ols         ri-clpm ## 3 0.04822117     3   ols         ri-clpm ## 4 0.04696841     4   ols         ri-clpm ## 5 0.07474887     5   ols         ri-clpm

title: Simulation and the crossLag Package
text: number data simulation functions package. One random-intercept cross-lagged panel regression. function creates lavaan syntax simulates data \(\texttt{lavaan}\). call returns list, one element \(\texttt{data}\) one \(\texttt{model}\). , example, syntax four wave dataset. can fit model using \(\texttt{lavaan}\). , instance, let’s use \(\texttt{monteCarlo}\) simulation function vary within person stability – jointly – x y, 1000 times. results fixing cross-lag effect x y 0.  effect \(y\) unstable, vary \(x\).  Varying \(x\) xnd \(y\). graph stability value \(y\), y-axis stability value \(x\).
code: simulate_riclpm(          waves = 4,          stability.p = 0.9,          stability.q = 0.9,          cross.p = 0.1,          cross.q = 0.1,          variance.p = 1,          variance.q = 1,          cov.pq = 0.5)$data %>% head() ##            x1         y1         x2         y2         x3         y3        x4 ## 1  0.99982812  0.4068819  1.7418094  2.3464627  1.7013029  1.7732967  2.046755 ## 2 -0.26749595  2.1388097  2.5434295  2.1142662  1.2703638  3.8885879  3.168168 ## 3  1.52309243 -0.8949587  1.8611301  1.1628661  1.3794057 -1.2160852  2.652900 ## 4 -0.91576415 -0.4653294 -1.3666753  0.8804835  0.7041079  1.6206294  2.934414 ## 5  0.01053924 -0.3734601  0.2167635 -0.0795669 -3.7255518  0.1711857 -4.978202 ## 6 -2.60533934 -1.7286504 -3.5175774 -2.6375363 -2.0835889 -2.7476928 -2.176048 ##           y4           U       kappa       omega ## 1  2.6366688  1.50462718  0.40645143  0.40645139 ## 2  3.5553827 -0.64779087 -0.20970804 -0.20970804 ## 3  0.1520823 -1.68064243 -0.86519976 -0.86519981 ## 4  4.8759890  0.01331896 -0.14020274 -0.14020274 ## 5 -1.6892058  0.03811347  0.01040741  0.01040743 ## 6 -1.4500491  0.45538096 -0.68029130 -0.68029129 simulate_riclpm(          waves = 4,          stability.p = 0.9,          stability.q = 0.9,          cross.p = 0.1,          cross.q = 0.1,          variance.p = 1,          variance.q = 1,          cov.pq = 0.5)$model %>% cat() ##  ## x1 ~ mu1*0 ## y1 ~ pi1*0 ## x2 ~ mu2*0 ## y2 ~ pi2*0 ## x3 ~ mu3*0 ## y3 ~ pi3*0 ## x4 ~ mu4*0 ## y4 ~ pi4*0 ## kappa ~~0.25* kappa ##                                           ## omega ~~0.25* omega ##                                           ## kappa ~~0.25* omega ## p1 =~ 1*x1 ## q1 =~ 1*y1 ## p2 =~ 1*x2 ## q2 =~ 1*y2 ## p3 =~ 1*x3 ## q3 =~ 1*y3 ## p4 =~ 1*x4 ## q4 =~ 1*y4 ##  p4 ~ 0.9 * p3 + 0.1 * q3 ##  q4 ~ 0.9 * q3 + 0.1 * p3 ##  p3 ~ 0.9 * p2 + 0.1 * q2 ##  q3 ~ 0.9 * q2 + 0.1 * p2 ##  p2 ~ 0.9 * p1 + 0.1 * q1 ##  q2 ~ 0.9 * q1 + 0.1 * p1 ##  p1 ~~ 1 * p1 ##  q1 ~~ 1 * q1 ##  p1 ~~ 0.5 * q1 ##  p2 ~~ 1 * p2 ##  q2 ~~ 1 * q2 ##  p2 ~~ 0.5 * q2 ##  p3 ~~ 1 * p3 ##  q3 ~~ 1 * q3 ##  p3 ~~ 0.5 * q3 ##  p4 ~~ 1 * p4 ##  q4 ~~ 1 * q4 ##  p4 ~~ 0.5 * q4 ##  p1 ~ 0  * U ##  q1 ~ 0 * U ##  p2 ~ 0  * U ##  q2 ~ 0 * U ##  p3 ~ 0  * U ##  q3 ~ 0 * U ##  p4 ~ 0  * U ##  q4 ~ 0 * U ##  U ~~ 0.5*U dat = simulate_riclpm(          waves = 4,          stability.p = 0.9,          stability.q = 0.9,          cross.p = 0.1,          cross.q = 0.1,          variance.p = 1,          variance.q = 1,          cov.pq = 0.5)$data   dat <- dat %>% select(-omega, -kappa) # Fit lavaan model lavaan::lavaan(model_syntax_clpm(waves = 4, model_type = "ri-clpm"), data= dat) ## lavaan 0.6-19 ended normally after 58 iterations ##  ##   Estimator                                         ML ##   Optimization method                           NLMINB ##   Number of model parameters                        27 ##   Number of equality constraints                     4 ##  ##   Number of observations                           500 ##  ## Model Test User Model: ##                                                        ##   Test statistic                                39.771 ##   Degrees of freedom                                13 ##   P-value (Chi-square)                           0.000 load("~/Dropbox/github_repos/crossLag_p/crossLag/tmp/sim_crosslag.RData") library(ggridges) riDat %>%   filter(within_person_stability_x == 0 ) %>%   ggplot(aes(x = xlag, fill = as.factor(round(within_person_stability_y, 2)), y = as.factor(round(within_person_stability_y, 2)))) +   geom_density_ridges2(     alpha = 0.25,     scale = 1,     show.legend = FALSE,     quantile_lines = TRUE,     rel_min_height = 0.01,     quantiles = 0.5,     calc_ecdf = FALSE,     jittered_points = TRUE,     position = position_points_jitter(width = 0.05, height = 0),     point_shape = 3,     point_size = 1,     point_color = "darkgrey",     point_alpha = 0.01,     fill = "blue",     color = NA  # Remove the outline    ) +   scale_x_continuous("", limits = c(-0.25, 0.25)) +   scale_y_discrete("") +   theme_minimal()  +   # Draw a vertical line at 0 that is dashed, use abline   geom_vline(xintercept = 0, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +   geom_hline(yintercept = 3, linetype = "dashed", color = "black") +   annotate("text", x = 0, y = 3, label = "True Value ", hjust = 0) +   ggtitle("Simulations varying the stability of Y across waves") +   # Style the plot   theme(     plot.title = element_text(size = 20, face = "bold"),     axis.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),     axis.text = element_text(size = 12),     legend.title = element_text(size = 15, face = "bold"),     legend.text = element_text(size = 12)   ) ## Picking joint bandwidth of 0.00369

title: Latent variable models for estimating cross-lagged effects in R
Latent variable models for estimating cross-lagged effects in R
text: package develops analytic framework analyze panel data tradition Cross Lagged Panel Model – CLPM. repository contains code written Stanley Feldman, Adam Panish, Bang Zheng Chris Weber improve upon designs using CLPM. Cross-Lagged Panel Model (CLPM) model pioneered Campbell (1963) well Campbell Stanley (1963) oft used, intuitive method test competing causal processes. model requires estimation lagged effects, including lag dependent variable. analyzing lagged effects (influence one variable later time point), researchers often purport gain insights direction strength causal relationships. language causal reasoning, Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) CLR model can expanded incorporate commonly encountered data issues arising CLPM, mediation, confounding, collision.

what: Reshape Data from Wide to Long Format for Cross-Lagged Analysis — reshape_long_sim_cr
title: Reshape Data from Wide to Long Format for Cross-Lagged Analysis — reshape_long_sim_cr
text: function takes wide-format data frame containing variables named 'x1', 'x2', ..., 'xn', 'y1', 'y2', ..., 'yn', reshapes long format suitable cross-lagged analysis. resulting data frame includes columns individual ID, wave, x, y, xlag (lagged x), ylag (lagged y).

title: Simulate data from a latent change model, two variables. — simulate_latent_change_multiple
text: Create simulated dataset two variable, based latent change score parameters. follows McArdle's review "Latent Variable Modeling Differences Changes Longitudinal data. McArdle JJ. Latent variable modeling differences changes longitudinal data. Annu Rev Psychol. 2009;60:577-605. doi: 10.1146/annurev.psych.60.110707.163612. PMID: 18817479.

title: Simulate data from a latent change model, two variables. — simulate_latent_change_multiple
code: simulate_latent_change_multiple(   waves = 10,   latent.true.variance_x = 1,   observed.residual.var_x = 0.1,   change.mean_x = 0.01,   constant.change.var_x = 0.1,   proportion.change_x = 0.02,   cov.change.true_x = 0.1,   latent.true.variance_y = 1,   observed.residual.var_y = 0.1,   change.mean_y = 0.1,   constant.change.var_y = 0.5,   proportion.change_y = 0.3,   cov.change.true_y = 0.1,   coupling_xy = 0.1,   coupling_yx = 0.1,   cov.xy.wave1 = 0.1,   cov.general = 0.1,   cov.x.general = 0.1,   cov.y.general = 0.1,   ... )

Variable x. change.mean_x mean latent change score factor. Variable x. constant.change.var_x Two types change modeled, proportional constant.  constant change variance. Variable x. proportion.change_x proportional change estimate. proportion previous wave's true score added current wave's true score. Variable x. cov.change.true_x covariance latent change initial true score, common factor wave 1. Variable x. latent.true.variance_y true score variance, variance latent. Variable y. observed.residual.var_y residual variance; variance observed data, waves 2 K. Variable y. change.mean_y mean latent change score factor. Variable y. constant.change.var_y Two types change modeled, proportional constant.  constant change variance. Variable y. proportion.change_y proportional change estimate. proportion previous wave's true score added current wave's true score. Variable y. cov.change.true_y covariance latent change initial true score, common factor wave 1. Variable y. cov.xy.wave1 covariance x y wave 1 cov.general covariance general change factors x y. slope.cov ...
